questions.statement: Soft iron is used as the core of an electromagnet instead of steel.
questions.reason: Soft iron is used because it easily gets magnetized when current flows and quickly loses its magnetism when current stops. Steel, being a hard material, would retain magnetism even after current is switched off, making it unsuitable for a temporary magnet that needs to be controlled.

questions.statement: An electromagnet is called a temporary magnet.
questions.reason: An electromagnet is called a temporary magnet because it retains the property of magnetism only when an electric current is passed through it. As soon as the current is stopped, the soft iron core loses its magnetism immediately.

questions.statement: Insulated copper wire is used in electromagnets instead of bare copper wire.
questions.reason: Insulated copper wire is used to prevent short circuits between adjacent turns of the coil. If bare wire is used, the turns would touch each other and current would flow directly without going through all the turns, making the electromagnet ineffective.
key_points: Ensures current flows through all turns

questions.statement: The hammer in an electric bell keeps striking the gong repeatedly when the push button is pressed.
questions.reason: This happens due to the make-and-break mechanism. When current flows, the electromagnet attracts the armature, causing hammer to hit gong and breaking the circuit. When circuit breaks, electromagnet loses magnetism and spring pulls armature back, completing circuit again. This cycle repeats continuously.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Electromagnets are preferred over permanent magnets in cranes for lifting scrap iron.
questions.reason: Electromagnets are preferred because their magnetism can be switched on and off. The crane can attract and lift scrap iron when current is on, and release it at the desired location by switching off the current. Permanent magnets cannot release the load easily.

questions.statement: Increasing the number of turns of the coil increases the strength of an electromagnet.
questions.reason: When the number of turns increases, more magnetic field is produced per unit length of the electromagnet. Each turn of wire carrying current contributes to the total magnetic field. Hence, the strength of the electromagnet is directly proportional to the number of turns.

questions.statement: Increasing the current increases the strength of an electromagnet.
questions.reason: When current increases, the magnetic field produced by each turn of the coil becomes stronger. Since the magnetic field is directly proportional to the current flowing through the conductor, the overall strength of the electromagnet increases with more current.

questions.statement: We cannot have a magnet with a single pole.
questions.reason: Every magnet must have two poles - north and south. Even if a magnet appears to have a single pole (like those sold with one pole covered), it still has both poles. One pole may be covered with adhesive or surrounded by a plastic or metal cup, but it exists.
key_points: Pole may be hidden but exists

questions.statement: The armature in an electric bell is made of iron.
questions.reason: Iron is used for the armature because it is a magnetic material that can be easily attracted by the electromagnet. When the electromagnet is energized, it attracts the iron armature towards itself, causing the hammer to strike the gong.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: An electric bell stops ringing when the push button is released.
questions.reason: When the push button is released, the circuit is broken at the switch itself. No current flows to the electromagnet, so it cannot attract the armature. The make-and-break cycle stops and the bell stops ringing.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Permanent magnets are made of hard materials while temporary magnets are made of soft materials.
questions.reason: Hard materials can retain magnetism for a long time once magnetized, making them suitable for permanent magnets. Soft materials easily gain magnetism in presence of a magnetic field but quickly lose it when the field is removed, making them suitable for temporary magnets like electromagnets.

questions.statement: Electromagnetic induction requires a change in magnetic field.
questions.reason: For electromagnetic induction to occur, there must be a change in the magnetic lines of force associated with the conductor. A constant magnetic field does not induce any current. Only when the magnetic field changes (increases, decreases, or moves), current is induced in the conductor.

questions.statement: Relative motion between magnet and conductor is essential for electromagnetic induction.
questions.reason: Without relative motion, there is no change in magnetic flux through the conductor. The magnetic lines of force cutting the conductor must change for current to be induced. Either the magnet or the conductor must move relative to the other.
key_points: No relative motion means no change in flux
Either magnet or conductor must move

questions.statement: The plastic coating is removed from the ends of copper wire when making an electromagnet.
questions.reason: The plastic coating acts as an insulator and prevents electrical contact. Removing it from the ends allows the bare copper to make proper electrical connection with the battery terminals, enabling current to flow through the wire.

questions.statement: Paper clips fall off the electromagnet when the switch is turned off.
questions.reason: When the switch is turned off, current stops flowing through the coil. Without current, the soft iron core loses its magnetism immediately because it has low retentivity. The paper clips are no longer attracted and fall off.

questions.statement: A galvanometer is used to detect induced current instead of an ammeter.
questions.reason: A galvanometer is more sensitive than an ammeter and can detect very small currents. Induced currents in simple experiments are often small. Additionally, a galvanometer can show the direction of current flow, which is important for understanding electromagnetic induction.

questions.statement: U-shaped electromagnets are preferred in electric bells over bar-shaped ones.
questions.reason: U-shaped electromagnets have both poles on the same side, creating a concentrated magnetic field. This provides stronger attraction for the armature compared to bar-shaped electromagnets where poles are at opposite ends. The stronger attraction makes the bell mechanism work more effectively.

questions.statement: The components of an electric bell are fitted on a wooden or plastic board.
questions.reason: Wood and plastic are insulators. Using an insulating board prevents short circuits and ensures current flows only through the intended circuit path. A metal board could create unwanted electrical connections between components.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Generators produce alternating current when a coil is rotated continuously.
questions.reason: As the coil rotates in the magnetic field, it cuts through magnetic lines of force in alternating directions. When moving one way, current flows in one direction; when moving the opposite way, current reverses. This continuous reversal produces alternating current.
key_points: Coil cuts field in alternating directions

questions.statement: Transformers only work with alternating current, not direct current.
questions.reason: Transformers use electromagnetic induction, which requires a changing magnetic field. AC continuously changes direction, creating a changing magnetic field in the primary coil. DC is constant, so it creates a constant magnetic field that cannot induce current in the secondary coil.

questions.statement: The wire in an electromagnet is wound tightly around the core.
questions.reason: Tight winding ensures maximum number of turns per unit length of the core. Since electromagnet strength is directly proportional to turns per unit length, tighter winding produces a stronger electromagnet. It also keeps the coil compact and prevents loose turns.

questions.statement: Electromagnets can be used to separate iron from non-magnetic waste in recycling.
questions.reason: Electromagnets attract only magnetic materials like iron and steel, while non-magnetic materials like plastic, glass, and aluminum remain unaffected. This allows efficient separation of iron from mixed waste, and the electromagnet can be switched off to release the collected iron.
key_points: Can release iron by switching off

questions.statement: Copper is used for making electromagnet coils instead of iron wire.
questions.reason: Copper is an excellent electrical conductor with very low resistance. It allows current to flow easily through the coil with minimal energy loss. Iron wire has higher resistance, would heat up more, and is magnetic which could interfere with the electromagnet's operation.

questions.statement: The strength of an induced current depends on the speed of relative motion.
questions.reason: Faster relative motion between magnet and conductor means faster change in magnetic flux through the conductor. Since induced current depends on the rate of change of magnetic flux, faster motion produces stronger induced current.
key_points: Induced current depends on rate of change

questions.statement: MRI machines use electromagnets instead of permanent magnets.
questions.reason: MRI machines require extremely strong and precisely controllable magnetic fields. Electromagnets can produce much stronger fields than permanent magnets and can be adjusted as needed. They can also be turned off for safety during emergencies or maintenance.
key_points: Can be turned off for safety

questions.statement: The contact screw in an electric bell is adjustable.
questions.reason: The adjustable screw allows fine-tuning of the gap between the armature and the screw. This controls how easily the circuit completes and breaks, affecting the speed and tone of the bell. It can be adjusted to optimize the bell's performance.
key_points: Controls gap between armature and screw
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.statement: Maglev trains can achieve very high speeds.
questions.reason: Maglev trains use electromagnets to levitate above the track, eliminating friction between wheels and rails. Without this friction, the only resistance is air resistance. The electromagnetic propulsion is also very efficient, allowing speeds over 600 km/h.

questions.statement: Halving the current in an electromagnet halves its strength.
questions.reason: The strength of an electromagnet is directly proportional to the current flowing through it. If current is halved, the magnetic field produced by each turn of wire is halved, resulting in half the overall magnetic strength.

questions.statement: A control experiment is needed when testing the electromagnet activity.
questions.reason: Without testing if the nail alone (without current) picks up paper clips, we cannot confirm that the current caused the magnetism. Some iron nails might already be slightly magnetized. A fair test requires comparing results with and without current to prove causation.

questions.statement: Reversing the battery connections in an electromagnet reverses its poles.
questions.reason: When battery connections are reversed, current flows in the opposite direction through the coil. The pole at each end depends on the direction of current flow (clockwise = south, anticlockwise = north). Reversing current reverses the direction at each end, swapping the poles.
